config.title: Properties that will be set directly on `Vue.config` for vue@2 and `app.config` for vue@3.

appTemplatePath.title: The path to a templated HTML file for rendering Nuxt responses.
appTemplatePath.description: Uses `<srcDir>/app.html` if it exists or the Nuxt default template if not.

store.title: Enable or disable vuex store.
store.description: By default is enbled if there is store / directory

head.title: Set default configuration for `<head>` on every page.

meta.title: Each item in the array maps to a newly-created <meta> element, where object properties map to attributes.

link.title: Each item in the array maps to a newly-created <link> element, where object properties map to attributes.

style.title: Each item in the array maps to a newly-created <style> element, where object properties map to attributes.

script.title: Each item in the array maps to a newly-created <script> element, where object properties map to attributes.

server.title: Whether to enable `fetch()` on the server.

client.title: Whether to enable `fetch()` on the client.

plugins.title: An array of nuxt app plugins.
plugins.description:
Each plugin can be a string (which can be an absolute or relative path to a file).
If it ends with `.client` or `.server` then it will be automatically loaded only
in the appropriate context.
It can also be an object with `src` and `mode` keys.
tags: { src: '~/plugins/client-only.js', mode: 'client' }, // only on client side
{ src: '~/plugins/server-only.js', mode: 'server' } // only on server side

extendPlugins.title: You may want to extend plugins or change their order. For this, you can pass
extendPlugins.description:
a function using `extendPlugins`. It accepts an array of plugin objects and
should return an array of plugin objects.

css.title: You can define the CSS files/modules/libraries you want to set globally
css.description:
(included in every page).
Nuxt will automatically guess the file type by its extension and use the
appropriate pre-processor. You will still need to install the required
loader if you need to use them.
tags: // Load a Node.js module directly (here it's a Sass file)

layouts.title: An object where each key name maps to a path to a layout .vue file.
layouts.description: Normally there is no need to configure this directly.

ErrorPage.title: Set a custom error page layout.
ErrorPage.description: Normally there is no need to configure this directly.

loading.title: Configure the Nuxt loading progress bar component that's shown between
loading.description:
routes. Set to `false` to disable. You can also customize it or create
your own component.

color.title: CSS color of the progress bar

failedColor.title: CSS color of the progress bar when an error appended while rendering
failedColor.description: the route (if data or fetch sent back an error for example).

height.title: Height of the progress bar (used in the style property of the progress bar).

throttle.title: In ms, wait for the specified time before displaying the progress bar.
throttle.description: Useful for preventing the bar from flashing.

duration.title: In ms, the maximum duration of the progress bar, Nuxt assumes that the
duration.description: route will be rendered before 5 seconds.

continuous.title: Keep animating progress bar when loading takes longer than duration.

rtl.title: Set the direction of the progress bar from right to left.

css.title: Set to false to remove default progress bar styles (and add your own).

loadingIndicator.title: Show a loading spinner while the page is loading (only when `ssr: false`).
loadingIndicator.description:
Set to `false` to disable. Alternatively, you can pass a string name or an object for more
configuration. The name can refer to an indicator from [SpinKit](https://tobiasahlin.com/spinkit/)
or a path to an HTML template of the indicator source code (in this case, all the
other options will be passed to the template.)

pageTransition.title: Used to set the default properties of the page transitions.
pageTransition.description:
You can either pass a string (the transition name) or an object with properties to bind
to the `<Transition>` component that will wrap your pages.

layoutTransition.title: Used to set the default properties of the layout transitions.
layoutTransition.description:
You can either pass a string (the transition name) or an object with properties to bind
to the `<Transition>` component that will wrap your layouts.

features.title: You can disable specific Nuxt features that you do not want.

store.title: Set to false to disable Nuxt vuex integration

layouts.title: Set to false to disable layouts

meta.title: Set to false to disable Nuxt integration with `vue-meta` and the `head` property

middleware.title: Set to false to disable middleware

transitions.title: Set to false to disable transitions

deprecations.title: Set to false to disable support for deprecated features and aliases

validate.title: Set to false to disable the Nuxt `validate()` hook

asyncData.title: Set to false to disable the Nuxt `asyncData()` hook

fetch.title: Set to false to disable the Nuxt `fetch()` hook

clientPrefetch.title: Set to false to disable prefetching behavior in `<NuxtLink>`

componentAliases.title: Set to false to disable extra component aliases like `<NLink>` and `<NChild>`

componentClientOnly.title: Set to false to disable the `<ClientOnly>` component (see [docs](https://github.com/egoist/vue-client-only))

rootDir.title: Define the workspace directory of your application.
rootDir.description:
This property can be overwritten (for example, running `nuxt ./my-app/`
will set the `rootDir` to the absolute path of `./my-app/` from the
current/working directory.
It is normally not needed to configure this option.

srcDir.title: Define the source directory of your Nuxt application.
srcDir.description: If a relative path is specified it will be relative to the `rootDir`.
tags: This would work with the following folder structure:

buildDir.title: Define the directory where your built Nuxt files will be placed.
buildDir.description:
Many tools assume that `.nuxt` is a hidden directory (because it starts
with a `.`). If that is a problem, you can use this option to prevent that.

dev.title: Whether Nuxt is running in development mode.
dev.description: Normally you should not need to set this.

test.title: Whether your app is being unit tested

debug.title: Set to true to enable debug mode.
debug.description: By default it's only enabled in development mode.

env.title: The env property defines environment variables that should be available
env.description:
throughout your app (server- and client-side). They can be assigned using
server side environment variables.
Note**: Nuxt uses webpack's `definePlugin` to define these environment variables.
This means that the actual `process` or `process.env` from Node.js is neither
available nor defined. Each of the `env` properties defined here is individually
mapped to `process.env.xxxx` and converted during compilation.
Note**: Environment variables starting with `NUXT_ENV_` are automatically injected
into the process environment.

createRequire.title: Set the method Nuxt uses to require modules, such as loading `nuxt.config`, server
createRequire.description: middleware, and so on - defaulting to `jiti` (which has support for TypeScript and ESM syntax).

target.title: Whether your Nuxt app should be built to be served by the Nuxt server (`server`)
target.description:
or as static HTML files suitable for a CDN or other static file server (`static`).
This is unrelated to `ssr`.

ssr.title: Whether to enable rendering of HTML - either dynamically (in server mode) or at generate time.
ssr.description:
If set to `false` and combined with `static` target, generated pages will simply display
a loading screen with no content.

modern.title: Whether to produce a separate modern build targeting browsers that support ES modules.
modern.description:
Set to `'server'` to enable server mode, where the Nuxt server checks
browser version based on the user agent and serves the correct bundle.
Set to `'client'` to serve both the modern bundle with `<script type="module">`
and the legacy bundle with `<script nomodule>`. It will also provide a
`<link rel="modulepreload">` for the modern bundle. Every browser that understands
the module type will load the modern bundle while older browsers fall back to the
legacy (transpiled) bundle.
If you have set `modern: true` and are generating your app or have `ssr: false`,
modern will be set to `'client'`.
If you have set `modern: true` and are serving your app, modern will be set to `'server'`.

modules.title: Modules are Nuxt extensions which can extend its core functionality and add endless integrations
modules.description:
Each module is either a string (which can refer to a package, or be a path to a file), a
tuple with the module as first string and the options as a second object, or an inline module function.
Nuxt tries to resolve each item in the modules array using node require path
(in `node_modules`) and then will be resolved from project `srcDir` if `~` alias is used.
Note**: Modules are executed sequentially so the order is important.

buildModules.title: Modules that are only required during development and build time.
buildModules.description:
Modules are Nuxt extensions which can extend its core functionality and add endless integrations
Each module is either a string (which can refer to a package, or be a path to a file), a
tuple with the module as first string and the options as a second object, or an inline module function.
Nuxt tries to resolve each item in the modules array using node require path
(in `node_modules`) and then will be resolved from project `srcDir` if `~` alias is used.
Note**: Modules are executed sequentially so the order is important.
tags: Note**: Using `buildModules` helps to make production startup faster and also significantly
decreases the size of `node_modules` in production deployments. Please refer to each
module's documentation to see if it is recommended to use `modules` or `buildModules`.

globalName.title: Allows customizing the global ID used in the main HTML template as well as the main
globalName.description: Vue instance name and other options.

globals.title: Customizes specific global names (they are based on `globalName` by default).

serverMiddleware.title: Server middleware are connect/express/h3-shaped functions that handle server-side requests. They
serverMiddleware.description:
run on the server and before the Vue renderer.
By adding entries to `serverMiddleware` you can register additional routes or modify `req`/`res`
objects without the need for an external server.
You can pass a string, which can be the name of a node dependency or a path to a file. You
can also pass an object with `path` and `handler` keys. (`handler` can be a path or a
function.)
tags: // Will register file from project server-middleware directory to handle /server-middleware/* requires
// We can create custom instances too
Note**: If you don't want middleware to run on all routes you should use the object
If you pass a string handler, Nuxt will expect that file to export a default function
// req is the Node.js http request object
// res is the Node.js http response object
// next is a function to call to invoke the next middleware
// Don't forget to call next at the end if your middleware is not an endpoint!
Alternatively, it can export a connect/express/h3-type app instance.
Alternatively, instead of passing an array of `serverMiddleware`, you can pass an object
whose keys are the paths and whose values are the handlers (string or function).

modulesDir.title: Used to set the modules directories for path resolving (for example, webpack's
modulesDir.description:
`resolveLoading`, `nodeExternals` and `postcss`).
The configuration path is relative to `options.rootDir` (default is current working directory).
Setting this field may be necessary if your project is organized as a yarn workspace-styled mono-repository.

dir.title: Customize default directory structure used by nuxt.
dir.description: It is better to stick with defaults unless needed.

assets.title: The assets directory (aliased as `~assets` in your build)

app.title: The directory containing app template files like `app.html` and `router.scrollBehavior.js`

layouts.title: The layouts directory, each file of which will be auto-registered as a Nuxt layout.

middleware.title: The middleware directory, each file of which will be auto-registered as a Nuxt middleware.

pages.title: The directory which will be processed to auto-generate your application page routes.

static.title: Your static directory, which will be directly accessible via the Nuxt server and copied
static.description: across into your `dist` folder when your app is generated.

store.title: The folder which will be used to auto-generate your Vuex store structure.

extensions.title: The extensions that should be resolved by the Nuxt resolver.

styleExtensions.title: The style extensions that should be resolved by the Nuxt resolver (for example, in `css` property).

alias.title: You can improve your DX by defining additional aliases to access custom directories
alias.description:
within your JavaScript and CSS.
Note**: Within a webpack context (image sources, CSS - but not JavaScript) you _must_ access
your alias by prefixing it with `~`.
Note**: If you are using TypeScript and want to use the alias you define within
your TypeScript files, you will need to add the aliases to your `paths` object within `tsconfig.json` .

ignoreOptions.title: Pass options directly to `node-ignore` (which is used by Nuxt to ignore files).

ignorePrefix.title: Any file in `pages/`, `layouts/`, `middleware/` or `store/` will be ignored during
ignorePrefix.description: building if its filename starts with the prefix specified by `ignorePrefix`.

ignore.title: More customizable than `ignorePrefix`: all files matching glob patterns specified
ignore.description: inside the `ignore` array will be ignored in building.

watch.title: The watch property lets you watch custom files for restarting the server.
watch.description:
`chokidar` is used to set up the watchers. To learn more about its pattern
options, see chokidar documentation.

watchers.title: The watchers property lets you overwrite watchers configuration in your `nuxt.config`.

rewatchOnRawEvents.title: An array of event types, which, when received, will cause the watcher to restart.

editor.title: Your preferred code editor to launch when debugging.

hooks.title: Hooks are listeners to Nuxt events that are typically used in modules, but are also available in `nuxt.config`.
hooks.description:
Internally, hooks follow a naming pattern using colons (e.g., build:done).
For ease of configuration, you can also structure them as an hierarchical object in `nuxt.config` (as below).

privateRuntimeConfig.title: Runtime config allows passing dynamic config and environment variables to the Nuxt app context.
privateRuntimeConfig.description:
It is added to the Nuxt payload so there is no need to rebuild to update your configuration in
development or if your application is served by the Nuxt server. (For static sites you will still
need to regenerate your site to see changes.)
The value of this object is accessible from server only using `$config`.
It will override `publicRuntimeConfig` on the server-side.
It should hold _private_ environment variables (that should not be exposed on the frontend).
This could include a reference to your API secret tokens.

publicRuntimeConfig.title: Runtime config allows passing dynamic config and environment variables to the Nuxt app context.
publicRuntimeConfig.description:
It is added to the Nuxt payload so there is no need to rebuild to update your configuration in
development or if your application is served by the Nuxt server. (For static sites you will still
need to regenerate your site to see changes.)
The value of this object is accessible from both client and server using `$config`. It should hold env
variables that are _public_ as they will be accessible on the frontend. This could include a
reference to your public URL.

quiet.title: Suppresses most of the build output log.
quiet.description: It is enabled by default when a CI or test environment is detected.

analyze.title: Nuxt uses `webpack-bundle-analyzer` to visualize your bundles and how to optimize them.
analyze.description:
This option is normally enabled by the CLI argument `--analyze`.
Set to `true` to enable bundle analysis, or pass [an object with options](https://github.com/webpack-contrib/webpack-bundle-analyzer#options-for-plugin).

profile.title: Enable the profiler in webpackbar.
profile.description: It is normally enabled by CLI argument `--profile`.

extractCSS.title: Enables Common CSS Extraction using
extractCSS.description:
[Vue Server Renderer guidelines](https://ssr.vuejs.org/guide/css.html).
Using [extract-css-chunks-webpack-plugin](https://github.com/faceyspacey/extract-css-chunks-webpack-plugin/) under the hood, your CSS will be extracted
into separate files, usually one per component. This allows caching your CSS and
JavaScript separately and is worth trying if you have a lot of global or shared CSS.
tags: If you want to extract all your CSS to a single file, there is a workaround for this.
However, note that it is not recommended to extract everything into a single file.
Extracting into multiple CSS files is better for caching and preload isolation. It
can also improve page performance by downloading and resolving only those resources

cssSourceMap.title: Enables CSS source map support (defaults to true in development)

ssr.title: Creates special webpack bundle for SSR renderer. It is normally not necessary to change this value.

parallel.title: Enable [thread-loader](https://github.com/webpack-contrib/thread-loader#thread-loader) when building app with webpack.

standalone.title: Inline server bundle dependencies
standalone.description: This mode bundles `node_modules` that are normally preserved as externals in the server build.
tags: @warning Runtime dependencies (modules, `nuxt.config`, server middleware and the static directory) are not bundled.
This feature only disables use of [webpack-externals](https://webpack.js.org/configuration/externals/) for server-bundle.
@note You can enable standalone bundling by passing `--standalone` via the command line.

publicPath.title: If you are uploading your dist files to a CDN, you can set the publicPath to your CDN.
tags: @note This is only applied in production.
The value of this property at runtime will override the configuration of an app that

serverURLPolyfill.title: The polyfill library to load to provide URL and URLSearchParams.

filenames.title: Customize bundle filenames.
filenames.description: To understand a bit more about the use of manifests, take a look at [this webpack documentation](https://webpack.js.org/guides/code-splitting/).
tags: @note Be careful when using non-hashed based filenames in production
as most browsers will cache the asset and not detect the changes on first load.
This example changes fancy chunk names to numerical ids:

loaders.title: Customize the options of Nuxt's integrated webpack loaders.

terser.title: Terser plugin options.
terser.description: Set to false to disable this plugin, or pass an object of options.
tags: @note Enabling sourceMap will leave `//# sourceMappingURL` linking comment at
the end of each output file if webpack `config.devtool` is set to `source-map`.

aggressiveCodeRemoval.title: Hard-replaces `typeof process`, `typeof window` and `typeof document` to tree-shake bundle.

optimizeCSS.title: OptimizeCSSAssets plugin options.
optimizeCSS.description: Defaults to true when `extractCSS` is enabled.

minimize.title: Set minimize to false to disable all minimizers. (It is disabled in development by default)

minimizer.title: You can set minimizer to a customized array of plugins.

splitChunks.title: Whether to split code for `layout`, `pages` and `commons` chunks.

corejs.title: Nuxt will automatically detect the current version of `core-js` in your project (`'auto'`),
corejs.description: or you can specify which version you want to use (`2` or `3`).

plugins.title: An array of Babel plugins to load, or a function that takes webpack context and returns
plugins.description:
an array of Babel plugins.
For more information see [Babel plugins options](https://babeljs.io/docs/en/options#plugins)
and [babel-loader options](https://github.com/babel/babel-loader#options).

presets.title: The Babel presets to be applied.
presets.description:
Note**: The presets configured here will be applied to both the client and the server
build. The target will be set by Nuxt accordingly (client/server). If you want to configure
the preset differently for the client or the server build, please use presets as a function.
Warning**: It is highly recommended to use the default preset instead customizing.

transpile.title: If you want to transpile specific dependencies with Babel, you can add them here.
transpile.description:
Each item in transpile can be a package name, a function, a string or regex object matching the
dependency's file name.
Tou can also use a function to conditionally transpile, the function will receive a object ({ isDev, isServer, isClient, isModern, isLegacy }).

minify.title: Configuration for the html-minifier plugin used to minify HTML files created
minify.description:
during the build process (will be applied for all modes).
Attention**: If you make changes, they won't be merged with the defaults!

template.title: Allows setting a different app template (other than `@nuxt/vue-app`)

templates.title: You can provide your own templates which will be rendered based
templates.description:
on Nuxt configuration. This feature is specially useful for using with modules.
Templates are rendered using [`lodash.template`](https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.15#template).
tags: src: '~/modules/support/plugin.js', // `src` can be absolute or relative
dst: 'support.js', // `dst` is relative to project `.nuxt` dir
// Options are provided to template as `options` key

watch.title: You can provide your custom files to watch and regenerate after changes.
watch.description: This feature is specially useful for using with modules.

deprecated.default: vendor has been deprecated since nuxt 2

default.deprecated: vendor has been deprecated since nuxt 2

$meta.deprecated: vendor has been deprecated since nuxt 2

stats.title: Set to `'none'` or `false` to disable stats printing out after a build.

friendlyErrors.title: Set to `false` to disable the overlay provided by [FriendlyErrorsWebpackPlugin](https://github.com/nuxt/friendly-errors-webpack-plugin)

additionalExtensions.title: Additional extensions (beyond `['vue', 'js']` to support in `pages/`, `layouts/`, `middleware/`, etc.)

followSymlinks.title: Set to true to scan files within symlinks in the build (such as within `pages/`).

$meta.deprecated: vendor has been deprecated since nuxt 2

loading.title: The text that displays on the Nuxt loading indicator when `ssr: false`.

error_404.title: The 404 text on the default Nuxt error page.
error_404.default: This page could not be found

server_error.title: The text to display on the default Nuxt error page when there has been a server error.

nuxtjs.title: The text (linked to nuxtjs.org) that appears on the built-in Nuxt error page.

back_to_home.title: The text (linked to the home page) that appears on the built-in Nuxt error page.

server_error_details.title: The message that will display on a white screen if the built-in Nuxt error page can't be rendered.
server_error_details.default: An error occurred in the application and your page could not be served. If you are the application owner, check your logs for details.

client_error.title: The default error title (if there isn't a specific error message) on the built-in Nuxt error page.

client_error_details.title: The error message (in debug mode) on the built-in Nuxt error page.
client_error_details.default: An error occurred while rendering the page. Check developer tools console for details.

default.error_404: This page could not be found
default.server_error_details: An error occurred in the application and your page could not be served. If you are the application owner, check your logs for details.
default.client_error_details: An error occurred while rendering the page. Check developer tools console for details.

bundleRenderer.title: Use this option to customize the Vue SSR bundle renderer.
bundleRenderer.description:
This option is skipped if `ssr: false`.
Read [docs for Vue 2](https://ssr.vuejs.org/api/#renderer-options) here.

crossorigin.title: Configure the crossorigin attribute on `<link rel="stylesheet">` and `<script>`

resourceHints.title: Adds prefetch and preload links for faster initial page load time.
resourceHints.description: You probably don't want to disable this option unless you have many pages and routes.

ssr.title: Whether to enable rendering of HTML - either dynamically (in server mode) or at generate time.
ssr.description:
This option is automatically set based on global ssr value if not provided.
This can be useful to dynamically enable/disable SSR on runtime after image builds
(with docker for example).

ssrLog.title: Forward server-side logs to the browser for better debugging (only available in development)
ssrLog.description: Set to `collapsed` to collapse the logs, or false to disable.

push.title: Set to true to enable HTTP2 push headers

pushAssets.title: You can control what links to push using this function. It receives `req`,
pushAssets.description:
`res`, `publicPath` and a `preloadFiles` array.
You can add your own assets to the array as well. Using `req` and `res`
you can decide what links to push based on the request headers, for example
using the cookie with application version.
Assets will be joined together with `,` and passed as a single `Link` header.

static.title: Configure the behavior of the `static/` directory.

prefix.title: Whether to add the router base to your static assets.
prefix.description: Note**: some URL rewrites might not respect the prefix.

compressor.title: Configure server compression.
compressor.description:
Set to `false` to disable compression. You can also pass an object of options
for [compression middleware](https://www.npmjs.com/package/compression), or
use your own middleware by passing it in directly - for example,
`otherComp({ myOptions: 'example' })`.

etag.title: To disable etag for pages set `etag: false`. See
etag.description:
[etag docs](https://github.com/jshttp/etag) for possible options.
You can use your own hash function by specifying etag.hash:
tags: In this example we are using `murmurhash-native`, which is faster
for larger HTML body sizes. Note that the weak option is ignored
when specifying your own hash function.

csp.title: Use this to configure Content-Security-Policy to load external resources. [Read more](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/CSP).
csp.description:
Set to `true` to enable, or you can pass options to fine-tune your CSP options.
Prerequisites**:
These CSP settings are only effective when using Nuxt with `mode: 'server'`
to serve your SSR application.
Updating settings**:
These settings are read by the Nuxt server directly from `nuxt.config.js`.
This means changes to these settings take effect when the server is restarted.
There is no need to rebuild the application to update CSP settings.
tags: The following example allows Google Analytics, LogRocket.io, and Sentry.io
To learn what tracking link you should use.

dist.title: Options used for serving distribution files. Only applicable in production.

fallback.title: Configure fallback behavior for [`serve-placeholder` middleware](https://github.com/nuxt/serve-placeholder).
fallback.description: Example of allowing `.js` extension for routing (for example, `/repos/nuxt.js`):

mode.title: Configure the router mode.
mode.description: For server-side rendering it is not recommended to change it.

base.title: The base URL of the app. For example, if the entire single page application is
base.description:
served under /app/, then base should use the value '/app/'.
This can be useful if you need to serve Nuxt as a different context root, from
within a bigger web site.

routeNameSplitter.title: This allows changing the separator between route names that Nuxt uses.
routeNameSplitter.description:
Imagine we have the page file `pages/posts/_id.vue`. Nuxt will generate the
route name programmatically, in this case `posts-id`. If you change the routeNameSplitter
config to `/` the name will change to `posts/id`.

middleware.title: Set the default(s) middleware for every page of the application.

linkExactActiveClass.title: Globally configure `<nuxt-link>` default exact active class.

linkPrefetchedClass.title: Globally configure `<nuxt-link>` default prefetch class (feature disabled by default)

extendRoutes.title: You can pass a function to extend the routes created by Nuxt.

scrollBehavior.deprecated: router.scrollBehavior` property is deprecated in favor of using `~/app/router.scrollBehavior.js` file, learn more: https://nuxtjs.org/api/configuration-router#scrollbehavior
scrollBehavior.title: The `scrollBehavior` option lets you define a custom behavior for the scroll
scrollBehavior.description:
position between the routes. This method is called every time a page is
rendered. To learn more about it.

parseQuery.title: Provide custom query string parse function. Overrides the default.

stringifyQuery.title: Provide custom query string stringify function. Overrides the default.

fallback.title: Controls whether the router should fall back to hash mode when the browser
fallback.description:
does not support history.pushState but mode is set to history.
Setting this to false essentially makes every router-link navigation a full
page refresh in IE9. This is useful when the app is server-rendered and needs
to work in IE9, because a hash mode URL does not work with SSR.

prefetchLinks.title: Configure `<nuxt-link>` to prefetch the code-splitted page when detected within
prefetchLinks.description: the viewport. Requires [IntersectionObserver](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Intersection_Observer_API) to be supported (see [Caniuse](https://caniuse.com/intersectionobserver)).

prefetchPayloads.title: When using nuxt generate with target: 'static', Nuxt will generate a
prefetchPayloads.description:
payload.js for each page.
With this option enabled, Nuxt will automatically prefetch the payload of the
linked page when the <nuxt-link> is visible in the viewport, making instant navigation.

trailingSlash.title: If this option is set to true, trailing slashes will be appended to every
trailingSlash.description:
route. If set to false, they'll be removed.
Attention**: This option should not be set without preparation and has to
be tested thoroughly. When setting `trailingSlash` to something else than
undefined, the opposite route will stop working. Thus 301 redirects should
be in place and your internal linking has to be adapted correctly. If you set
`trailingSlash` to true, then only example.com/abc/ will work but not
example.com/abc. On false, it's vice-versa

timing.title: Enabling timing adds a middleware to measure the time elapsed during
timing.description:
server-side rendering and adds it to the headers as 'Server-Timing'.
Apart from true/false, this can be an object for providing options.
Currently, only `total` is supported (which directly tracks the whole
time spent on server-side rendering.

badgeMessages.title: Add a message to the CLI banner by adding a string to this array.

bannerColor.title: Change the color of the 'Nuxt.js' title in the CLI banner.

dir.title: Directory name that holds all the assets and generated pages for a `static` build.

routes.title: The routes to generate.
routes.description:
If you are using the crawler, this will be only the starting point for route generation.
This is often necessary when using dynamic routes.
It can be an array or a function.
tags: You can pass a function that returns a promise or a function that takes a callback. It should
return an array of strings or objects with `route` and (optional) `payload` keys.
return res.data.map(user => ({ route: '/users/' + user.id, payload: user }))
If `routes()` returns a payload, it can be accessed from the Nuxt context.

exclude.title: An array of string or regular expressions that will prevent generation
exclude.description: of routes matching them. The routes will still be accessible when `fallback` is set.

concurrency.title: The number of routes that are generated concurrently in the same thread.

interval.title: Interval in milliseconds between two render cycles to avoid flooding a potential

subFolders.title: Set to `false` to disable creating a directory + `index.html` for each route.

fallback.title: The path to the fallback HTML file.
fallback.description:
Set this as the error page in your static server configuration, so that unknown
routes can be rendered (on the client-side) by Nuxt.
If unset or set to a falsy value, the name of the fallback HTML file will be `200.html`.
If set to true, the filename will be `404.html`.
If you provide a string as a value, it will be used instead.
Note**: Multiple services (e.g. Netlify) detect a `404.html` automatically. If
you configure your web server on your own, please consult its documentation
to find out how to set up an error page (and set it to the 404.html file)

crawler.title: Set to `false` to disable generating pages discovered through crawling relative

manifest.title: Set to `false` to disable generating a `manifest.js` with a list of all generated pages.

nojekyll.title: Set to `false` to disable generating a `.nojekyll` file (which aids compatibility with GitHub Pages).

cache.title: Configure the cache (used with `static` target to avoid rebuilding when no files have changed).

ignore.title: An array of files or directories to ignore. (It can also be a function that returns an array.)

globbyOptions.title: Options to pass to [`globby`](https://github.com/sindresorhus/globby), which
globbyOptions.description: is used to generate a 'snapshot' of the source files.

dir.title: The directory underneath `/_nuxt/`, where static assets (payload, state and manifest files) will live.

base.title: The full path to the directory underneath `/_nuxt/` where static assets
base.description: (payload, state and manifest files) will live.

versionBase.title: The full path to the versioned directory where static assets for the current buidl are located.

version.title: A unique string to uniquely identify payload versions (defaults to the current timestamp).
